Topic.Title: Facebook shares will hit the $5 area within three months.

Message.Msg: Nemesis: Facts matter too. I first rode AMZN down from 240 to the 175 area last year. Made a health profit. I didn't reenter until AMZN hit 230. I rode it down to 215 and sold all of my OOM puts before earnings, holding only my DITM position. I am gradually increasing my position and will ultimately make a killing on this scam. I always beat these scams because I understand the psychological games being played (behaviorial investing) and I always maintain a sufficient cash hedge to see through the capitulation squeezes. Everyone said the same crap to me about GMCR and then NFLX as a short. Then, when I pivoted and went long GMCR (which, I will note that I haven't heard of any of the major shorts doing that) at $17, I got mocked for being stupid going long a company that would be bankrupt... Yet, I was proved right (what is that, over 90% since I pivoted and went long?). You are a two bit momentum player who simply does not understand the limited economic value capture potential behind AMZN. It is building an infrastructure to dominate distribution of electronic content, yet the consumer will be agnostic as to where it buys its electronic content when everyone has a cloud service. AAPL, GOOG and others will match (or beat since they can) the price that AMZN charges and it will simply have huge overhead costs, an overgrown physical distrbution presence and limited cash flow to support it. Truly, this will prove epic if AAPL and GOOG fight back hard and given that AMZN pulled out a bull whip, it is hard to imagine they won't pull an Indiana Jones and use the revolver...

Topic.Title: This new format sucks!!! No wonder yahoo stock a TURD!!

Message.Msg: Two possible reasons: 1. Yahoo can't make money so they devise a format that makes you have to click more on things i.e, you can't see as much of the board as you could before without going further down the message list which you can't do without clicking on something. This makes their eyeballs numbers go up. In this way some bright management guru told them they can maybe charge advertisers more for ads.... 2. This format looks better (they think) on a cell/smart phone which is where they think most of their monetizable eyeballs come from so yahoo management thinks it will be cool, like animating the list of messages so it looks like a camera panning or gliding up the new list, a pesudo page flip effect...

Message.Msg: I'd have to look back at it for the specifics, but I probably entered last year somewhere below $240. But, I more than doubled up at $240 for the ride to around $175, at which time I took profits to focus elsewhere. What I do know is that I was up significantly (over $50K) on AMZN in 2011 and that I did not reenter until the move to 230 earlier this year. I don't care what you believe. There are plenty of people that have read my posts on NFLX, GMCR, LULU, CMG, GOOG, AAPL, NSPH that know my track record. What matters is where AMZN will go from here. Simply stated, I am correct that AMZN will find it exceptionally difficult to extract extraordinary economic rents on the distribution of digital content... AAPL, GOOG and others can match AMZN's content pricing is hosed as it does not have proprietary razorblades and everyone will buy them for the same amount and can sell them for the same amount.

Message.Title: NTWK $5.4 …UP AGAIN AFTER MONSTER EARNINGS AND 40% REVENUE GROWTH & $1/SHARE 2013 GUIDANCE...PRICE TARGET RAISED TO $16......NTWK ANNOUNCED ITS SECOND CLOUD DIVISION LAST WEEK…The stock is just starting to rally after monster earnings/guidance and with a 3 million share float $15 soon is just around the corner (see chart). That would make it a 12 forward PE which is conservative for a company expecting to deliver $1/share net income and grow revenues 40% in 2013.........still very cheap even at $15
Message.Msg: SHORT TERM TARGET $10+ .......2013 GUIDANCE: 40% GROWTH AND $1/SHARE NET INCOME NTWK ANNOUNCED ITS SECOND CLOUD DIVISION LAST WEEK AFTER EXPONENTIAL RECENT REVENUE EXPLOSION OF IT'S FIRST (VROOZI) CLOUD DIVISION 3M SHARE FLOAT......AFTER EARNINGS PROFIT TAKING OVER.....MAGNIFICENT CHART In addition to legacy license-based products gaining strong momentum, the company's cloud divisions are starting to show significant growth as well. The company's Cloud division Vroozi is growing exponentially NTWK announced a new North America cloud business unit last week. Larger companies are swallowing fast growing enterprise cloud providers with SAP and ORCL certification and compatibility. "We made a calculated decision to enter this growing market given our years of experience as a software developer, the minimal investment required, and the revenue potential given just the breadth of our current relationships," said Najeeb Ghauri, chairman and CEO of NetSol. "I am fully confident in our highly capable team, reinforced by our talented group of IT professionals, to scale the business quickly and capture a portion of this burgeoning industry, creating an additional revenue driver and further diversifying our revenue mix by geography." "What we are offering, in essence, is private cloud performance at an elastic cloud price -- giving potential customers in our target market segment the performance, flexibility, reliability, and a no-nonsense fixed pricing model that they have long desired," added Imran Haider, COO of NetSol North America and head of NetSolCloudVM. "As a growing software company ourselves, we have critical insights into the efficiency and productivity needs of NetSolCloudVM's target customer base and look forward to unveiling our new services in the coming months." In its updated public cloud forecast in June, Gartner estimated that IaaS was the fastest growing cloud segment with a projected GAGR of 41.7%, and exceeding a $20 billion global market by 2016. ===== 4Q and FY 2012 EARNINGS SUMMARY......9/4/2012 NetSol Technologies Reported RECORD Fiscal Fourth Quarter and Year-End Results - 9/4/2012 - Fourth Quarter 2012 Revenue Surges to an all-time quarterly record of $14.3 Million on Increased License Revenues and associated maintenance and service agreements going forward - Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Advance Significantly to $0.25 per Diluted Share - Full Year 2012 revenues a record $38M - Full Year 2012 Earnings of $0.39/share - Company Expects Record Fiscal 2013 Annual Revenue Growing over 30% to $46 million to $49 million, With Earnings per Diluted Share Advancing to $0.80 to $1.00 - Per the CC, Company anticipates doubling revenues and net income by 2015 NTWK HIGHLIGHTS: - Only 3 million share float - Fast growing profitable US-based global cloud and license-based software company with 8 offices worldwide (US, China, Australia, UK, Pakistan, Singapore, Thailand, Saudi Arabia) – - Trading at 5 PE and 1 times sales – This is about 25% of sector average - Revenues are increasing at double digit rates, - Guidance calls for 30% revenue growth in 2013 - 3 consecutive quarters of profitability, - Guidance calls for $1/share net income in 2013!!! - Global alliances with Mercedes Benz and SANY Corp of China. - No. 1 in China and the APAC region in its niche market of leasing and financing software - It’s Vroozi Division is a fast growing Cloud Computing Play with strong relations with SAP, ORCL, MSFT. - Vroozi’s SAP-approved smartOCI procurement search catalog software built on SaaS is being adopted rapidly. Revenues exploded in 4Q 2012 and are expected to multiply in 2013 and a big reason for the 30%+ 2013 projected revenue increase - Vroozi has been created as independent entity to potentially IPO it or sell it to a cloud-acquiring giant like SAP and others - Strong balance sheet with $1/share Cash - With every license they sell a lucrative 5-year service and maintenance agreement building strong recurrent revenues - Huge and consistent insider buying. Insiders bought over 5% of the outstanding shares since 2010 - Strong institutional investor support grew to almost 20% from 11% last year - NTWK has over 50 Fortune 100 loyal customers. Never lost a customer. None of the customers is over 5% of the total revenues - partial customer list: CitiGroup, Mercedes Benz, Santander, BMW, Volvo, Ford, GE Capital, Cisco Capital, Paribas, GMAC, Toyota, Nissan, Hyundai, BYD, SANY Corp. China, etc.

Message.Title: AMZN now worth the same as INTC...
Message.Msg: Makes complete sense... AMZN has that cloud thingy... Which Google, Rackspace, HP Cloud and even new entrants are targeting. Intel servers power all of those cloud thingies (and those simply will not be replaced by ARM chips -- FINFET/Haswell will further amplify the value proposition)... AMZN that tablet thingy that it sells for cost hoping to make the money on content. Intel dominates microprocessor manufacturing globally, has huge margins and cash flow. INTC is out of favor because it was behind in mobile/tablet, primarily due to power consumption. INTC's FINFET manufacturing technology will provide superior power consumption and a vastly more capable processor and I suspect AAPL will likely adopt it in next gen tablets -- Christmas 2013 -- to further differentiate performance and to diversify away from Samsung. AMZN trades at over 57X EBITDA (and a much higher multiple of true FCF). Intel trades at 4.6X EBITDA. I'm sure Geeg and Nemesis will argue that buying INTC is buying a dead company. Because "price is truth". We'll see where these two companies are next April... I just bought 100C April 2013 INTC $25 calls as a starting position. I plan on quadrupling it if Intel continues to fall...

Topic.Title: Core Competency in Loosing Money

Message.Msg: The best part is that AMZN will have opened itself up to a very aggressive content price war from Apple and Google. Neither makes their money on content, but since AMZN adopted a loss leader strategy attacking their core, they have ample right to respond. Needless to say, they have more cash, a larger installed base and a superior ecosystem... They will win. If you read the article I just posted, you'll see Apple is matching prices. Just the beginning. Wonder what Amazon's ROIC is going to go to when Apple and Google carve into Amazon's existing digital content sales and all it is left with is capital intensive warehouse/logistics on low value added goods that now collect sales taxes....

Topic.Title: AMZN now worth the same as INTC...

Message.Msg: Sybs: In short, yes. I'll make a little extra coin long on the ride up to 1550 or higher, all of which will be redeployed into this scam. I cannot wait for the content price war to go full throttle. Apple has nothing material to lose (content and apps contribute little to Apple's bottom line). With an aggressive hit now, Amazon will find itself overcommitted on Kindle orders while losing cash flow on the digital content front. Apple simply needs to match Amazon's price and offer a 10% credit on the first $250 worth of content (costs Apple a maximum of $25 per user while taking much of that revenue from Amazon's Kindle store). It will be fun to see what Amazon's largest shareholders are really willing to pay for Amazon when it has to issue a secondary because it loses its cash machine and it has committed to tons of capital leases for warehouses it never should have built...

Topic.Title: Core Competency in Loosing Money

Message.Msg: LOIC - loss on invested capital - they are fighting wars on two fronts - physical merchandise and electronic and will loose on both fronts. They are less efficient in both camps and they keep digging themselves a bigger and bigger hole. More warehouses, more logistics, more services, more engineers, more advertising spend, more optimization, more free services - and for what? Bezos said best tablet on the market regardless of price - well then, why not actually profit from the thing! He wouldn't want to jeopardize "long term" strategy, of course not. Look everyone will be buying stuff with this thing so get it in their hands, right? For what? Proof will be in quarterly report after report that demonstrates. proves beyond anyone's doubt, they are less efficient and will return little cash or profit to stakeholders.

Message.Title: Fire HD Review by Walt Mossberg
Message.Msg: after testing the 7-inch Kindle Fire HD, I can’t agree with the sweeping claim that it is “the best tablet at any price.” The Fire HD isn’t as polished, fluid or versatile as the iPad. It offers only a fraction of the third-party apps available on either the iPad or the Nexus 7 (and other standard Android tablets). I found that after prolonged use, the Fire HD showed signs of latency—apps and content displayed delays in launching. This latency disappeared after a reboot. The Fire HD also assaults users with ads occupying the entire screen every time they start or resume using it. You have to pay Amazon another $15, using an obscure setting on a Web page, to escape these ads. And there are pitches to buy more content on many other screens, even those displaying your already-purchased content. I found the screen to be crisp, clear and vivid, though inferior to the superb Retina display on the current iPad. Its resolution is the same as that of the Nexus 7. It also is about the same thickness as the Nexus, though a bit heavier. It is much lighter than the larger iPad, but about 10% thicker. I found its speakers far better than those on the iPad and Nexus. Amazon claims the new Fire has advanced Wi-Fi technology that is faster than the Wi-Fi on the iPad. But in my tests, I couldn’t replicate that. Most Web pages I tried loaded slightly faster on the iPad. And, using two different speed test utilities on two different networks, I found the iPad was a bit faster in almost every instance, occasionally much faster. In my harsh battery test, where I set the screen at 75% brightness, leave on the Wi-Fi to collect email in the background, and play videos back to back, the Fire HD was respectable, if not up to its claim of 11 hours, or as good as its competitors. It lasted nine hours and 28 minutes, compared with just five hours and 47 minutes for the original Fire. That was about half an hour less than the iPad, but over an hour less than the Nexus.

Of course, there will be not only the iPad cycle, but another round of launches from the Google/Motorla and the Asian Jelly Bean tablets for Christmas... Topic.Title: Fire HD Review by Walt Mossberg

Message.Msg: I saw the 10" Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 @ COST for $330. Unit comes with a microSD slot. Very smooth navigation. Why would anyone pay $300 plus $15 for a 9" Scamazon tablet with a forked OS?

Message.Title: NYT Pogue: More Soot than Fire
Message.Msg: I’m not exactly sure what’s been seeping into the water supply at Amazon’s Seattle offices, but it’s making the executives a little loopy. Amazon’s executives are hailing the new touch-screen tablet, the Kindle Fire HD, as “the best tablet at any price.” They’re hailing Amazon’s new touch-screen tablet, the Kindle Fire HD, as “the best tablet at any price.” Well, let’s see now. The Fire HD has no camera on the back, no GPS navigation, no speech recognition, no to-do list or notes app. It trails the iPad in thickness, screen size, screen sharpness, Web speed, software polish and app availability. It can only dream of the iPad’s universe of accessories, cases and docks..

Topic.Title: NYT Pogue: More Soot than Fire

Message.Msg: The Fire doesn’t come with a wall charger; that’s $10 extra at purchase time, or $20 later. Without it, you have to charge from a computer’s USB jack — and even then, the Kindle doesn't charge unless it's asleep or its brightness is turned down. (Rival tablets charge just fine from the same jacks.) ... “the best tablet at any price?” Hmmm. Somebody should put a call in to the Seattle water inspectors.
